{{about|the political institution}} {{refimprove|date=April 2012}} The '''Shadow Cabinet''' is a senior group of opposition spokespeople in the [[Westminster system]] of government who together under the leadership of the [[Opposition (parliamentary)|Leader of the Opposition]] form an alternative cabinet to the government's, whose members ''shadow'' or mark each individual member of the Cabinet.<ref name="glossary">{{cite web|title=Shadow Cabinet: Glossary |url=http://www.parliament.uk/site-information/glossary/shadow-cabinet/ |publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref> Members of a shadow cabinet are often but not always appointed to a Cabinet post if and when their party gets into government. It is the Shadow Cabinet's responsibility to pass criticism on the current government and its respective legislation, as well as offering alternative policies.
==Cultural applications== In the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Canada]] the major opposition party and specifically its shadow cabinet is called ''His'' or ''[[Official Opposition (United Kingdom)|Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Her Majesty’s Opposition, SN/PC/3910 |url=http://www.parliament.uk/documents/commons/lib/research/briefings/snpc-03910.pdf|work=Commons Standard Notes|publisher=Library of the House of Commons, UK Parliament|accessdate=22 September 2012|author=Mary Durkin|coauthors=Oonagh Gay|date=21 June 2006|quote=This note outlines the rights and privileges of Her Majesty’s Loyal Opposition, or the Official Opposition, as the party with the second largest number of seats within the House of Commons is known.}}</ref> The adjective "loyal" is used because, while the role of the opposition is to oppose [[Her Majesty's Government]], it does not dispute the [[Constitutional monarchy|sovereign]]'s right to the throne and therefore the legitimacy of the government. However in other countries that use the Westminster system (for example, [[New Zealand]]), the opposition is known simply as ''The Parliamentary Opposition'' instead of shadow.
Some parliamentary parties, notably the [[Australian Labor Party]], elect all the members of their shadow cabinets in a party room ballot, with the Leader of the Opposition then allocating portfolios to the Shadow Ministers.<ref>{{cite web|title=In The Shadows: The Shadow Cabinet in Australia|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/binaries/library/pubs/monographs/bateman/preliminary.pdf|publisher=Parliament of Australia: Department of Parliamentary Services|author=Joel Bateman|accessdate=22 September 2012}} ISBN 978-0-9806554-0-7</ref> In other parliamentary parties, the membership and composition of the Shadow Cabinet is generally determined solely by the Leader of the Opposition.
In most countries, a member of the shadow cabinet is referred to as a '''Shadow Minister'''. In Canada, however, the term '''[[Opposition Critics]]''' is more usual. In the United Kingdom's [[House of Lords]], the term "spokesperson" is used instead of "shadow".<ref name="glossary" />
In many jurisdictions, [[third party (politics)|third parties]] (which are neither participant in the government or in the official opposition) may also form their own parliamentary front benches of critics; however, parliamentary standing orders on the right for parties to speak often dictate that the right to speak can only be granted to a party or group if a minimum number of members can be recorded by the party. In Ireland, for example, [[technical group]]s are often formed by third parties and independent [[Teachtaí Dála|TD]]s in the [[Dáil Éireann]] in order to increase the members' right to speak against larger parties which can afford the right to speak as Front Benches in Government or Opposition.<ref>{{cite web|title=Technical group makes voice heard and gives bigger parties run for their money|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/0111/1224310102423.html|publisher=Irish Times|accessdate=18 May 2012|author=HARRY McGEE|date=January 11, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TDs agree to form Dáil technical group|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2011/0309/1224291667861.html|publisher=Irish Times|accessdate=18 May 2012|date=Wed 03 Mar 2011}}</ref>
